questions.question:
Question 1: What is the most common cause of intestinal obstruction in children younger than 2 years of 
age?
questions.explanation:
The most common cause of intestinal obstruction in children < 2 years of age is 
intussusception. Intussusception occurs when a segment of the intestine, constricted by a wave of peristalsis, 
telescopes into the immediately distal segment. It is usually idiopathic at younger ages. However, 
it can be associated with viral infections and rotavirus vaccines, perhaps due to reactive 
hyperplasia of Peyer patches. Untreated intussusception may progress to intestinal obstruction, compression of mesenteric 
vessels, and infarction. Note: The most common form of congenital intestinal atresia is imperforate anus. It occurs due to 
failure of the cloacal diaphragm to involute. 1026 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question:
Question 2: A 30-year-old man presented with a history of long-standing diarrhea. Serologic evaluation 
showed positive anti-tissue transglutaminase antibodies. Duodenal biopsy showed crypt 
hyperplasia, villi atrophy, and CD8+ cells in lamina propria. Which of the following HLA 
alleles is associated with this condition?
questions.explanation:
The given scenario is suggestive of celiac disease or gluten-sensitive enteropathy. It is associated 
with HLA-DQ2 and HLA-DQ8 alleles. It is an immune-mediated enteropathy triggered by the ingestion of gluten-containing foods such 
as barley, rye, oats, and wheat (mnemonic: BROW) in genetically predisposed individuals. In these individuals, digestion of the gluten-containing diet leads to the formation of gliadin 
peptides. These peptides result in the following immune reactions: • They can activate the epithelial cells to express certain cytokines (IL-15), which result in CD8+ T 
cell proliferation • They undergo deamidation and interact with HLA-DQ2 or HLA-DQ8 on the antigen-presenting 
cells. This leads to CD4+ T cell stimulation and further cytokine production These mechanisms result in epithelial tissue damage. Antibodies associated with celiac disease are: • Anti-gliadin antibodies • Anti-tissue transglutaminase antibodies (anti-ttG) • Anti-endomysial antibodies Microscopic findings include: • Villi atrophy and flattening • Crypt hyperplasia • Increased intraepithelial T cells

questions.question:
Question 3: A 34-year-old male patient presented to the clinic with a history of diarrhea and poor 
appetite. He has been having 4-5 episodes of non-bloody, loose stools per day for the last 3 
months. A duodenal biopsy is taken and the histopathology is as shown below. Which of the 
following is the most common cancer associated with this condition? 1021 
Sold by @itachibot
questions.explanation:
The given scenario and histopathology findings are suggestive of celiac disease. 
Enteropathy-associated T-cell lymphoma is the most common cancer associated with celiac 
disease. 1027 
Sold by @itachibot Small intestinal adenocarcinoma is also associated with celiac disease. Celiac disease or celiac sprue or gluten-sensitive enteropathy is triggered by the ingestion of 
gluten, which is the major storage protein of wheat and similar grains. It usually affects the 2nd 
part of the duodenum or proximal jejunum. Antibodies associated with celiac disease are: • Anti-gliadin antibodies • Anti tissue transglutaminase antibodies • Anti endomysial antibodies MARSH's score is used to assess celiac disease histologically. Dermatitis herpetiformis occurs in about 10% of patients with celiac disease. 1028 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question: Question 4: Malabsorption is not due to intestinal mucosal defects in which of the following disorders?
questions.explanation:
In cystic fibrosis, malabsorption occurs due to exocrine pancreatic insufficiency, not intestinal 
mucosal defects. Cystic fibrosis is caused by pathogenic mutations in the CFTR gene on chromosome 7 that 
encodes the cystic fibrosis transmembrane conductance regulator (CFTR) protein. The absence of CFTR protein interferes with Na+, HCO3-, and water secretion resulting in 
defective luminal hydration. This causes the formation of pancreatic intraductal concretions and 
causes exocrine pancreatic insufficiency.

questions.question:
Question 5: A 33-year-old man presented to the ER with severe abdominal pain. He gives a history of 
fever for the past 2 weeks. On examination, faint salmon-colored macules were noted on the 
trunk and abdomen. Which of the following diseases would you suspect?
questions.explanation:
The given clinical scenario of faint salmon-colored macules is suggestive of rose spots that are 
seen in typhoid fever. Rose spots are small erythematous maculopapular lesions that are seen on the chest and 
abdomen. In the second week of illness, abdominal pain develops and rose spots may be seen, as 
shown in the following image. Note: Typhoid ulcers are oval ulcers oriented along the axis of the ileum and carry the risk of 
perforation. They usually develop in the 3rd week of typhoid.

questions.question: Question 6: Which of the following phases is impaired in patients diagnosed with Whipple's disease?
questions.explanation:
In Whipple's disease, the cause of malabsorption is impaired lymphatic transport. In Whipple disease, clinical symptoms occur because organism-laden macrophages accumulate 
within the small intestinal lamina propria and mesenteric lymph nodes, causing lymphatic 
obstruction. These bacteria-laden macrophages also accumulate within mesenteric lymph nodes, 1029 
Sold by @itachibot synovial membranes of affected joints, cardiac valves, brain. The clinical presentation of Whipple disease is usually a triad of diarrhea, weight loss, and 
arthralgia.

questions.question:
Question 7: A 35-year-old HIV-positive man is referred for evaluation of malabsorption. A duodenal 
biopsy shows the following finding. Which special stain can be used further to confirm the 
diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
This clinical scenario and image showing distended foamy macrophages inside the lamina propria 
are characteristic of Whipple's disease. The diagnosis can be confirmed by acid-fast staining. Distended foamy macrophages inside the lamina propria of the duodenum can be seen in: • Whipple's disease • Intestinal tuberculosis, particularly in immunocompromised hosts As both organisms are PAS-positive, PAS staining cannot differentiate between the two diseases. 
On the other hand, acid-fast staining can be used to confirm the diagnosis, as only mycobacteria 
are acid fast, whereas Tropheryma whipplei is not.

questions.question:
Question 8: 1023 
Sold by @itachibot A 2-year-old boy was brought by his parents with complaints of vomiting, watery diarrhea, 
and fever. A rapid ELISA test for rotavirus was positive. Which of the following viral proteins 
causes damage to the intestinal epithelium?
questions.explanation:
Rotavirus damages the intestinal epithelium by a viral factor called non-structural protein 4 
(NSP4), which can induce epithelial apoptosis. Rotavirus is a common cause of severe childhood diarrhea and diarrheal mortality worldwide. 
Rotavirus selectively infects and destroys mature enterocytes in the small intestine. This causes 
repopulation of the villus surface by immature secretory cells. 1030 
Sold by @itachibot

Question 10: A 55-year-old man who presented with diarrhea and flushing was found to have an ileal 
tumor. The histological image of the resected specimen is given below. Which of the following 
markers will these cells be positive for?
questions.explanation:
The given history and histological image are diagnostic of ileal carcinoid. The tumor cells are 
typically positive for synaptophysin on immunohistochemistry. Histology of carcinoid typically reveals islands and nests of uniform cells with scant, pink granular 
cytoplasm and salt and pepper chromatin. Electron microscopy reveals cytoplasmic dense-core 
neurosecretory granules. 1031 
Sold by @itachibot Carcinoid tumors most commonly occur in the gastrointestinal tract. The most common sites in 
decreasing order of frequency are the appendix, ileum, and rectum. These tumors may cause 
carcinoid syndrome, which is characterized by cutaneous flushing, sweating, bronchospasm, 
colicky abdominal pain, diarrhea, and right-sided cardiac valvular fibrosis. Immunohistochemical (IHC) markers for carcinoid tumors are: • Neuron-specific enolase • Synaptophysin • Chromogranin A • Leu 7

questions.question:
Question 11: A 10 month old infant is brought to the OPD with complaints of intractable diarrhea. His past 
history is significant for autoimmune thyroiditis. On examination, eczematous rashes were 
seen on the chest and back. Sequencing of which of the following genes would help to arrive 
at a definitive diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
The given scenario is suggestive of autoimmune enteropathy or IPEX syndrome. Definitive 
diagnosis requires gene sequencing to identify mutations in the FOXP3 gene. FOXP3 is a transcription factor expressed in CD4+ regulatory T cells. Autoimmune enteropathy is an X-linked disorder characterized by severe persistent diarrhea and 
autoimmune disease in young children. A particularly severe familial form is termed IPEX an 
acronym denoting immune dysregulation, polyendocrinopathy, enteropathy, and X-linked 
inheritance. The classic presentation of IPEX is a triad of: • Failure to thrive with severe chronic diarrhea due to an autoimmune enteropathy • Autoimmune endocrinopathy (neonatal type 1 diabetes or thyroiditis) • Dermatitis (usually eczematous) 1032 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question:
Question 12: A 7-day-old infant was brought with complaints of profuse watery diarrhea and severe 
dehydration. On detailed evaluation, labs showed metabolic acidosis and electron microscopy 
of small bowel biopsy showed characteristic intracellular microvillus inclusions. Mutations in 
which of the following genes is associated with this condition?
questions.explanation:
The given scenario is suggestive of microvillus inclusion disease (MVID) which is associated with 
MYO5B gene mutations. Microvillus inclusion disease or Davidson disease is an autosomal recessive disorder due to 
mutations of MYO5B gene. This gene encodes a motor protein that is required for the transport of 
normal nutrients, ions, water, and plasma membrane components. Hence, it leads to defective 
vesicular transport that causes deficient brush-border assembly. Clinical features of MVID are: • Profuse watery, secretory diarrhea - before 3 months of age (often in the first few days of life) • Metabolic acidosis • Hypotonic dehydration Diagnosis of MVID include: • Electron microscopy - • Inclusion containing microvilli in the apical cytoplasm of the intestinal cells. • Brush border microvilli are poorly developed with only a few/blunted microvilli • Immunostaining of villin (the brush border protein) • CD10 immunohistochemistry to detect microvillus inclusions Treatment is total parenteral nutrition and small bowel transplantation. The following electron microscopy image shows characteristic intracytoplasmic inclusions that are 
lined by intact microvilli along the absorptive surfaces of the intestinal cells. 1033 
Sold by @itachibot Large Intestine - Non-Neoplastic Conditions
